Surface reconstruction phenomenon of substrate induced by strong interactions of heterointerfaces may result in the development of unusual physical and chemical properties. Here we adopt a simple method in which ultrathin Co3O4 nanomeshes (2.6 nm) are synthesized to increase the oxygen release under high temperature, allowing a phase transition for the two cobalt oxide types. With the introduction of S atoms in the conversion process, the exposed crystal plane of CoO changes from (0 1 ̅ 1 ) to ( 1 ̅ 11 ) owing to the restrictive effect of in-situ formed CoS thin film, which is the first time to reveal the restructuring of substrate under strong interface interactions of heterostructure. By creating abundant interfaces with subtle lattice distortion in CoS/CoO heterostructure, these special interfaces can be deemed as dominant active sites to accelerate the ORR/OER reaction. The CoS/CoO shows a considerable OER performance with an only 20 mV higher potential than IrO2 at 10 mA cm−2 and decent ORR performances, which realizes a half-wave potential of 0.82 V and high durability. This work may open up a promising way to rationally design hybrid catalysts for efficient and durable application of electrocatalytic devices. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Restructuring CoS/CoO Heterostructure Oxygen-involving catalyst Synergetic effect 1 Introduction Increasing concerns of global issues in the environment and energy have facilitated the researches and development of the transformation and storage systems in relation to renewable energy [1]. Oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) are two crucial processes towards energy storage and conversion systems but both suffer sluggish kinetics because of their complex multielectron transfer processes, thus it blocks technological progress for practical application [2,3]. Currently, Ir, Ru and their oxides are perceived to be the benchmark for OER, while Pt and its derivative materials occupy the position of the most effective ORR catalyst [4–6]. Nevertheless, the extensive application of electrocatalysts has been restricted by the scarcity and, exorbitant price, as well as poor stability [7,8]. Therefore, it is highly demanded to develop high-performance and low-cost oxygen-involving electrocatalysts. Controlled growth of nanomaterials, combined with the principle of catalysis and illustrated from well-defined model systems, has led to vigorous development in the field of rational catalyst design [9–13]. One particularly successful strategy has been to tune surface strain, and strongly chemisorbed adsorbates are well known to induce structural changes to catalyst surfaces [14,15]. For a heterogeneous catalytic process in traditional industrial catalysis, such as water-gas shift or CO oxidation reactions, the catalysts can easily undergo surface reconstruction when bond to the adsorbates to adopt the thermodynamically most stable structure at temperatures up to several hundred degrees Celsius [16–18], and even electrocatalytic reactions at room temperature are no exception [19–21]. However, this surface reconstruction phenomenon is often ignored in the actual catalyst synthesis process. The process of constructing heterostructured materials due to the different physicochemical properties and lattice structures of each individual component, it causes structural reconstruction on the catalyst surface [22–24]. At present, there is no established cognition for surface reconstruction phenomenon in constructing heterostructures. Engineering of interfaces located in heterostructures is central to the development of functional materials, because it can integrate distinctive component-specific properties into a single entity, thereby augmenting functionality [25–28]. The constructed interfacial structures can facilitate adsorption of reactants on the surface of the catalyst and charge transport [29–32]. In previous reports, significant efforts have been devoted to developing heterostructures using epitaxial growth, solution chemical processes, or other methods [23,33–35]. During the formation of heterostructures, heteroatoms adsorbed or deposited on the substrate surface nucleate on its surface. Corresponding heterogeneous interface may form rich defects, which is a common result of the metal atoms forming chemical bonds with the adsorbates to cause their small displacements [15,36–43]. Moreover, the atomically perfect heterostructure promises strong interfacial chemical and electronic interactions between heterogeneous components, which could control the lattice growth of heteroatoms [44]. For example, CoO (111) substrate governs the atomically epitaxial growth of Pt nanoparticles and determine its resulting atomic structure [45]. An analogously principle is also applied to the universality of the Au (001) surface reconstruction under 1 H MoS2 [46]. This strategy based on little lattice mismatch along with strong-electronic coupling can highly control the synthesis of hybrid catalysts, which reflects the restrictive effect of substrate on the nucleation of surface heteroatoms. Although there is a surge of interest in rich defects, high-dense heterointerfaces and heteroatom growth during constructing heterostructures with high-catalytic activities, there remain rarely explored at the surface reconstruction phenomenon of substrate by strong interactions of heterointerfaces. The direct study of catalyst nanoparticles is challenging because of the complexity of their structures. Model catalysts such as single crystals and vicinal surfaces have been widely investigated to understand the phenomenon of surface reconstruction [47,48]. In this work, in which CoO ultrathin nanomeshes with single-crystal structure are employed as a model system, we report the heterostructure of in-situ formed CoS thin film on the CoO substrate (CoS/CoO) through thermal sulfurizing. We unambiguously identify the key role of the restrictive effect of CoS hybrids for the crystal plane exposed on the CoO nanocrystals in the surface restructuring process, which makes the crystal plane of CoO thermally converted by Co3O4 change from (0 1 ̅ 1 ) to ( 1 ̅ 11 ) to form a little lattice mismatch with (001) crystal plane of CoS. By creating abundant interfaces in CoS/CoO heterostructure, these special interfaces can be deemed as dominant active sites to accelerate the ORR/OER reaction. The resulting CoS/CoO shows a considerable OER performance with an only 20 mA higher potential than IrO2 at 10 mA cm−2 and decent ORR performances, which realizes a half-wave potential of 0.82 V and high durability. Our findings reveal the concept that the interfacial-restrictive restructuring process of catalyst nanostructures and the catalytic performances of the restructured surface can be controlled by engineering the strong-interfacial interaction. 2 Experimental and theoretical section 2.1 Synthesis of precursor The precursor was obtained conforming to a typical hydrothermal method putted forward by the early study, that is, a certain volume of ammonia, 1 M sodium carbonate and 1 M Cobalt (II) nitrate hexahydrate solutions were sequentially added into the 15 mL ethylene glycol solvents every 2 min. After a stirring duration for 20 min, the mixture was turned into a homogeneous solution. Next, a Teflon liner autoclave (45 mL) was provided to accommodate the obtained liquor, and reacted in oven for 17 h. Afterwards, the products by naturally cooling to room temperature were washed by centrifugation with distilled water and ethanol. Finishing all the above steps, the precursor was obtained by drying at 40 ℃ in vacuum condition. 2.2 Synthesis of CoS/CoO The CoS/CoO heterostructure was prepared by the following method. The as-obtained precursor was firstly annealed in air to synthesize Co3O4 nanomeshes, the forming method of which was referred to the earlier literature as well. Then the Co3O4 nanomeshes and S powder in a weight ratio of 1:0.5 were placed at the downstream part and upstream position of the graphite boat, respectively to be annealed at 450 ℃ under Ar atmosphere to synthesize CoS/CoO heterostructure for 60 min. 2.3 Synthesis of CoO CoO was obtained by annealing Co3O4 nanomeshes at 450 ℃ in H2 atmosphere with the temperature rate of 1 ℃ min−1 maintained for 200 min. 2.4 Synthesis of CoS The CoS was obtained by the same strategy with that of CoS/CoO, excepting that the proportion of the Co3O4 and S powder is a weight ratio of 1:5. 2.5 Material characterization X-ray powder diffraction (XRD, Bruker D8 Advance) with Cu Kα radiation was conducted to analyze the configuration. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JEOL JSM-7800F) was applied to reveal the outward appearance. Transmission electron microscopy (JEOL JEM-2100, FEI Talos F200X and FEI Titan Cubed Themis G2 300) coupled with a probe corrector was conducted to validate lattice structure and distribution information of constituent elements. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) using an ESCALAB250 analyzer was applied for the determination of the chemical states. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller surface area measurement (BET, Quantachrome Autosorb-6B) coupled with a pore size analyzer was conducted to figure out the porous features as well as the surface area. 2.6 Electrochemical measurements Both ORR and OER tests were analyzed at room temperature by a three electrodes electrochemical system in 0.1 M KOH, prepared by pure KOH flakes (Aldrich, 99.99%). The working electrode was glassy carbon electrode, the geometric surface area of which is calculated to be 0.19625 cm2 stem from the 5 mm electrode diameter, and the counter electrode was graphite electrode. Typically, 3 mg synthesized samples dispersed in a mixture containing 100 μL 0.5 % Nafion and 300 μL ethanol, then ultrasonicated for at least 30 min to obtain a homogeneous ink. After that, the surface of glassy carbon electrode was covered by a certain volume of ink (mass loading of 0.2 mg cm−2). And the processing procedure of other samples was almost no differences. To make preparations for electrochemical tests, pure oxygen was persistently fed in the electrolyte around half hour to achieve O2-saturated solution. The polarization curves were calibrated by IR-compensation in OER and ORR. When the scan rate is maintained at 10 mV s−1, linear sweep voltammograms (LSV) with the gradually increasing rotating rate began at 400 rpm was tested to estimate the electrocatalytic property of ORR. To eliminate the deviation caused by bubbles on the surface of the electrode, OER measurements were performed in the same electrolyte environment with 1600 rpm. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurement was carried out from 100 kHz to 0.1 Hz with 5 mV voltage amplitude. Chronopotentiometry tests were used to investigate the OER stability. The potentials presented here were quoted against a reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) conforming to the Nernst equation and all the current densities were standardized except as otherwise noted. Koutecky-Levich (K-L) equations were applied as the reference to calculate the kinetic of ORR and electron transfer numbers (n): (S1) 1 j = 1 j L + 1 j K = 1 B ω 1 / 2 + 1 j K (S2) B = 0.2nFC 0 D 0 2/3 ν −1/6 (S3) j K = nFkC 0 Where J, Jk and JL are the measured current density, the kinetic current density, the diffusion-limiting current density separately, ω is the angular velocity of the disk, B is the slope of Koutecky-Levich (K-L) plots, n is the electrons transfer number, F is the Faraday constant (F = 96485 C mol−1), C0 is the bulk concentration of O2 (1.2 × 10−6 mol L−1), D0 is the diffusion coefficient of O2 in the electrolyte 0.1 M KOH (1.9 × 10−5 cm2 s−1), ν is the kinematic viscosity of the electrolyte (0.01 cm2 s−1), k is the electron-transfer rate constant. 2.7 Computation methods and models The computed results in this paper were calculated by using the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerh (PBE) [49] within the DFT framework as implemented in Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [50]. For the setting of wave functions, they were expanded in a plane wave basis, the truncated plane wave energy of which is 400 eV. A 2 × 2 × 1 Monkhorst-pack grid ƙ-points sampling was conducted for the calculation of slab. The gamma k-point was set for structure optimization for the CoS/CoO because of the large system. For the geometry optimizations, the force and energy cut-offs were set at 0.03 eV/Å and 10−5 eV. In pursuit of eliminating periodic interactions, a vacuum space of 12 Å was applied along the c direction normal to the surface of catalyst. Additionally, the on-site Coulomb interaction is considered by the PBE + U method because of the strong correlation effect among the partially filled Co states [51]. The values of U and J were set to fix at 4.1 and 0 eV, respectively, which is based on the earlier literature [52]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Material characterizations To obtain a single-crystal model Co3O4 nanocrystal, we first designed and synthesized the ultrathin hydrated precursor nanosheets by means of solution-phase methods, and then pyrolyzed them at 300 ℃ . The obtained Co3O4 phase was subsequently transformed to the CoO phase by a thermal conversion process at Ar atmosphere. The ultrathin Co3O4 nanomeshes have a uniform thickness ( 2.6 ± 0.2 nm), which confirmed by Atomic Force Microscope (AFM) image (Fig. S2). The clear lattice fringes align across the surface of Co3O4 and CoO (Fig. S3, and Fig. 1b, f), implying their single-crystalline structure. The d-spacings on the basal faces of Co3O4 are 0.29 and 0.24 nm, respectively, as well as that of CoO are 0.24 nm and 0.21 nm. And the corresponding selected-area electron diffraction (SAED) analysis indicates that the basal plane in each ultrathin nanomeshes with a face-centered cubic (fcc) structural phase is normal with respect to the [222] direction (Fig. 1c, g), with left and right faces formed by (220) planes for Co3O4, and side faces enclosed by (200) and (111) planes for CoO. The crystal structures of the two types of cobalt oxide nanomeshes examined by X-ray diffraction (XRD) (Fig. S4) are consistent with the fcc assignment. The calculated lattice spacings based on the XRD results are also in agreement with the measured values from the HR-TEM images of the ultrathin nanomeshes. The schematic illustration in Fig. 2a shows the synthesis of CoS/CoO heterostructures. In the vulcanization process, the O species was released from the Co3O4 under high temperature, then the sulfur atoms gradually replaced the released oxygen atoms to form the CoS, and the Co3O4 support was converted to CoO phase accordingly. The occurrence of a phase transition for the two cobalt oxide types is dependent on the inherent thermodynamic barrier of oxygen release or oxygen adsorption [53,54]. With the absence of oxygen atoms, the crystal structure of Co3O4 tends to be unstable and gradually transforms to CoO with lower energy level. Fig. 2b shows the semblable in-plane relationships for the special crystal face of Co3O4 and CoO, respectively. The corresponding HR-TEM images of Co3O4 after proper heat treatment at Ar atmosphere are observed in Fig. 2c and reveal crystal plane transformation process of Co3O4 to CoO. The lattice fringes of CoO (111) plane at 0.24 nm are determined by Co3O4 (222) plane duo to their parallel crystal structures. Another (200) plane of CoO with a smaller lattice spacing of 0.21 nm is transformed from Co3O4 (220) plane. The interface transition region between the crystal face of Co3O4 and CoO shows an irregular arrangement of atoms along the direction of Co3O4 (220) crystal plane (Fig. 2d), which is ascribed to the asymmetry of different lattice structures at heterogeneous interfaces [55]. The above results describe that the different types of lattice structures arising from new crystal forms of epitaxial growth or phase transformation in similar crystalline materials are constrained by the substrate lattice structure. The XRD patterns of Co3O4 sulfurized with different time are shown in Fig. 2e and Fig. S5. It can be concluded that Co3O4 undergoes surface restructuring to form CoO and epitaxially grows CoS thin films in situ due to the reduction of S atom at temperatures up to 450 ℃ . And then Co3O4 nanomeshes complete the transformation to CoS/CoO heterostructure. As the degree of vulcanization increases, CoS/CoO and CoS possess rounder corners and rougher surfaces (Fig. S6). Interestingly, the crystal plane exposed on in-situ formed CoS overlayer controls the surface structure of the resulting CoO converted from Co3O4 substrate. The HR-TEM images of intermediate phase of CoO/Co3O4 are displayed in Fig. 2e, f. The close lattice fringes of both CoS (100) and CoO (110) grow along the coincident lattice direction of Co3O4 (220) with around 0.29 nm. Moreover, the overlapped lattice fringes of CoS film and CoO nanomeshes are associated with the perfect interface. The strong interaction between the heterogeneous interface may be the cause of transition by CoO crystal plane. TEM image of CoS/CoO heterostructure displays the rougher and porous surface features in Fig. S7a. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area for CoS/CoO heterostructure is 277.7 m2/g, and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) model indicates that the pore size of as-obtained sample is approximately 5 nm, indicating the high porosity structure (Fig. S8). CoS/CoO heterostructure shows that CoS films are intimately contacted with CoO nanomeshes ( Fig. 3a and Fig. S7a). Their crystallographic characteristics are clearly revealed by the fast Fourier transformation (FFT) of CoO. The reciprocal-space information on CoO is well matched to that of CoS, giving the guidance for the growing CoS on CoO surface with strong coupling with electrons and chemistry. In Fig. 3b and Fig. S7b, the distinct interface boundary was marked between CoS and CoO domains. The lattice fringes with spacing of 0.29 nm are consist with the (010) and (100) facet of hexagonal CoS, meanwhile the (011) and (110) facet with the lattice spacing of 0.30 nm are ascribed to cubic CoO. In addition, the existent of stacking faults has been formed at interfaces, which may be caused by the interaction of different lattice structures at heterogeneous interfaces. High-angle annular dark-feld TEM (HAADF-TEM) image and the corresponding element mapping (Fig. 3c) show the Co, S, O elements in the heterostructure. Obviously, Co and O elements are uniformly dispersed on the whole CoS/CoO nanomeshes, while the S element is more concentrated and partially covers on CoO supports. To better understand the chemical states of elements in resultant sample, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) is adopted to determine elemental valence state and interfacial characteristics of the material. Fig. 3d shows the Co 2p spectrum of as-obtained samples, in which two peaks located at 781.6 eV and 797.7 eV demonstrate the existence of CoO bond, and the two satellite peaks located at 787.2 eV and 803 eV indicate the Co2+ [56]. Compared to CoO, the peaks of Co 2p in CoS/CoO can be observed to shift negatively, suggesting the electron transfer between the two ingredients. This interaction may cause the reactivity change of CoS around the interface. The pair of characteristic peaks at 778.9 eV and 793.9 eV are indexed to the CoS bond, which are the same as the situation in bare CoS (Fig. S9) [56,57]. As demonstrated in Figure 3e, O1, O2, and O3 peaks at 529.7 eV, 531.3 eV and 532 eV are indexed to CoO bonds, hydroxyl groups and oxygen vacancies, respectively [58–60]. The large peak areas of oxygen vacancies can be observed in CoS/CoO heterostructure. This might be attributed to the lattice oxygen loss at interfaces induced by the fabrication of sulfides on the surface of CoO, which may cause the lattice distortion. Meanwhile, the peaks of O 1s in CoS/CoO heterostructures show a negative shift compared with that of pristine CoO, suggesting the electrons transfer from S to O. As for the S 2p spectra (Fig. 3f), the peaks of S 2p3/2 and S 2p1/2 for synthesized samples are located at a more positive position than that of CoS, elucidating that the electrons transfer between CoO and CoS [61]. The strong electronic interaction between CoO and CoS indicates the existence of interfaces in CoS/CoO heterostructure, which is well consistent with the HRTEM results [62]. 3.2 Electrocatalytic performance of materials for ORR and OER The ORR properties of as-obtained electrocatalysts are evaluated firstly by rotating disk electrode (RDE) in 0.1 M KOH. To evidence the superiority of obtained heterostructures in oxygen-involving electrocatalysis, the electrochemical measurements for CoO, CoS, IrO2 and Pt/C are performed under same conditions as well. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) measurements are first tested under the rotating speed of 1600 rpm. CoS/CoO shows a satisfactory performance in the light of a high onset potential of 0.86 V, which outperforms that of CoO (0.67 V), CoS (0.81 V) and IrO2 (0.74 V) and is competitive to that of Pt/C (0.91 V) ( Fig. 4a). Moreover, the half-wave potential of CoS/CoO is 0.82 V, which is 50 mV close to that of Pt/C (0.87 V) (Fig. 4c). By comparison, it can be suggested that the synergistic catalysis combined by CoS and CoO in the heterostructure may be instructive to the enhanced electrochemical activities of CoS/CoO. The Tafel slopes of CoS/CoO and Pt/C are approximately equal (Fig. S10), indicating the ORR mechanism of as-synthesized catalysts may possess a mild disparity to Pt/C. In pursuit of a deeper insight into the ORR kinetics, the electron transfer number (n) is calculated conforming to Koutecky–Levich (K-L) equation for investigating the ORR pathways. From LSV curves in a gradually increasing rotating speeds from 400 to 2000 rpm (Fig. 4b and Fig. S11), the n of CoS/CoO can be calculated to be 3.87, indicating that the catalyst can function at alkaline condition via a predominantly four-electron reduction pathway for ORR. The K–L results of other contrast samples are shown in Fig. S12. These decent behaviors on CoS/CoO towards ORR may be attributed to the synergistically coupled CoS and CoO. Furthermore, the LSV curve after 10,000 cycles of the CoS/CoO exhibits almost no difference with the initial curve, displaying good stability in alkaline solution (Fig. S9,10). The OER catalytic behaviors of as-obtained electrocatalysts are also estimated in 0.1 M KOH with O2-saturated. As shown in Fig. 4d, the onset potential of CoS/CoO is 1.48 V, and it achieves a potential (Ej=10) of 1.55 V to enable the current density up to 10 mA cm−2, which shows a close approximation to that of IrO2 (onset potential is 1.45 V, Ej=10 = 1.53 V). Tafel slope is also studied for further understanding of the OER kinetics. CoS/CoO exhibits the smallest Tafel slope with reference to other measured materials, suggesting that the OER current density for CoS/CoO can increase rapidly with the increasing overpotential (Fig. S15) [63]. The electrochemical results in Fig. 3e imply that the synergistically catalyzed OER processes achieved in CoS/CoO heterostructure is instructive to improve performance. Moreover, the main Co2+ value in CoS/CoO confirmed by XPS may contribute to the improved OER performance, as it has been evidenced by Liu et al. that Co2+ promotes the oxygen ions interact with the catalyst surface, hence it is conducive to the formation of cobalt oxygydroxide (CoOOH) [64]. Further catalytic kinetics evaluation of CoS/CoO is derivative from electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements (Fig. S16). CoS/CoO possesses smallest diameter, which means it to undertake lower interface charge-transfer resistance. The specific OER activities were calculated via normalizing the current by the corresponding BET surface areas. As displayed in Fig. S17 and 18, the obviously high value of CoS/CoO heterostructure still displays the best OER activity among these Electrocatalysts, which conﬁrms the intrinsic optimization of active sites. Besides the electrochemical measurements mentioned above, the results of cyclic voltammetry (CV) cycling and chronoamperometric tests show negligible decay after evolution reaction, proving the high OER stability of CoS/CoO in measured alkaline electrolyte (Fig. S19 and Fig. S20). After long-time OER stability measurement, the XPS spectra of Co 2p is no significant change in Fig. S21a, and the S 2p spectrum indicates that the S atom has been slightly oxidized to form an S-O bond in Fig. S21b. In addition, The HR-TEM images of CoS/CoO heterostructures after 2500 CV cycles is displayed in Fig. S22. The CoO substrate still retains a good crystal structure with (111) plane exposure. The epitaxial CoS is slightly oxidized without surface restructuring process induced by the electrochemical conditions. Since the difference between the potential at 10 mA cm−2 (Ej=10) of OER and the half-wave potential (E1/2) of ORR is an important criterion to estimate bifunctional electrochemical behaviors, Fig. 4f and Table S1 show the calculated overvoltages. The difference value of CoS/CoO is 0.73 V, which is smaller than other tested catalysts and some reported cobalt sulfides or cobalt oxides containing bifunctional catalysts in 0.1 M KOH solution, suggesting that CoS/CoO possesses a preferable bifunctionality. 3.3 The density functional theory (DFT) calculations results To get a further insight into the interfacial electronic feature of the heterostructure, density functional theory (DFT) calculations are carried out. The crystallographic orientation relationship is based on the HRTEM results. Impressively, the (111) lattice plane of CoO and the (001) lattice plane of CoS matches well (Fig. S23), thus it is beneficial to form interfaces. Fig. S24 displays that the work functions of CoO (111) and CoS (001) surfaces are 7.698 and 5.666, respectively. This result means that the value of Fermi level for CoS (001) surface and CoO (111) surface are not the same. Obviously, CoO (111) has a higher Fermi level. Therefore, when CoS is synthesized on the CoO surface, electrons will flow from CoS to CoO until the two Fermi level reach to the same, which corresponds to the XPS results. To get an atomic-level understanding of the influence of the constructed O-Co-S interfaces on ORR performance, energy diagram for CoS, CoO and CoS/CoO calculated under alkaline conditions. As shown in Fig. 5a, under the standard ORR potentials, U = 1.23 V, the rate-determining step (*O + H2O + e- → *OH + OH-) for CoS requires a very high energy barrier of 1.443 eV. An energy barrier of 0.931 eV for CoO is needed to drive the similar rate-determining step (*O + H2O + e- → *OH + OH-), while for CoO/CoS, the energy barrier of the second electron transfer step (*OOH + e- → *O + OH-) is further decreased to 0.776 eV, manifesting faster ORR kinetics on the heterostructure. In Fig. 5b, decreasing the electrode potential U to 0 V leads to an exergonic elementary reaction. CoO/CoS and CoO both exhibit a free energy profile with no uphill step. For CoS, the rate-determining step is still uphill at U = 0 V, implying a larger overpotential to drive oxygen reduction. The proposed mechanism of ORR on the CoS/CoO is depicted in Fig. 5c. The DFT calculation results confirmed the superiority of the novel CoS/CoO heterostructure to catalyze ORR compared to CoS and CoO. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, we have introduced a brief way to generate a CoS/CoO bifunctional catalyst consisted of interfaces caused by the synthesis of CoS on CoO. Our experimental results suggest that the surface restructuring process and catalytic performances of CoO nanomeshes are controlled by CoS thin film. The strong synergistic interactions between CoS and CoO govern the surface restructuring and favorable electronic tuning of CoO. Owing to the abundant interfaces, in which CoS (001) matches well with CoO (111) by chemical binding, the CoS/CoO catalyst exhibits good catalytic behaviors for oxygen-involving reactions. This work affords the simple synthetic route and novel concept demonstration for the formation of advanced heterostructure. It may open up a promising way to replace noble catalysts by designing and synthesizing inexpensive electrocatalysts with heterostructure. coredata.dc:description: Surface reconstruction phenomenon of substrate induced by strong interactions of heterointerfaces may result in the development of unusual physical and chemical properties. Here we adopt a simple method in which ultrathin Co3O4 nanomeshes (2.6 nm) are synthesized to increase the oxygen release under high temperature, allowing a phase transition for the two cobalt oxide types. With the introduction of S atoms in the conversion process, the exposed crystal plane of CoO changes from (0 1 ̅ 1 ) to ( 1 ̅ 11 ) owing to the restrictive effect of in-situ formed CoS thin film, which is the first time to reveal the restructuring of substrate under strong interface interactions of heterostructure. By creating abundant interfaces with subtle lattice distortion in CoS/CoO heterostructure, these special interfaces can be deemed as dominant active sites to accelerate the ORR/OER reaction. The CoS/CoO shows a considerable OER performance with an only 20 mV higher potential than IrO2 at 10 mA cm−2 and decent ORR performances, which realizes a half-wave potential of 0.82 V and high durability. This work may open up a promising way to rationally design hybrid catalysts for efficient and durable application of electrocatalytic devices.
coredata.dc:title: Crystal-plane-controlled restructuring and enhanced oxygen-involving performances of bifunctional catalyst
